reviews.text: Both amazing and disappointing at the same time. The historical aspect is mind blowing, but the iconography is way too much!

Great church.  Large square out front.  There was an original church with Mosaic floors that can be seen in some places.  This was destroyed by Samaritans, then the crusaders set up a church there and they got run out.  Last it was revolt by the Ottomans.  You can see parts from each period.  Good shops across the street and cafes.  Excellent wood carving store with everything made from Olive wood.  Masses are held in the church but they are all in Arabic.  People still have baptisms, funerals, weddings, etc. Above Jesus' birth cave.  Long line to get into the cave but with certain registered guides you can enter in reverse and bypass the line.  There is a silver Star on the floor under the altar in the cave which is supposed to be the birth site.  Then opposite that wall is the manger (stone trough) where baby Jesus was laid.
Very well kept. Important place to visit for anyone. Like stepping through a time machine.
Visiting the church requires a lot of time as there are many people waiting to go into the cave of Nativity it takes sometime even 3 hours of waiting in the line...

Church of Nativity is a must visit as it houses the birthplace of Christ. A little bit closer to Palestine than Israel but the site is beautiful and the house is designed in gold and shiny materials which lots up the arena.

Herodion is a bit off the beaten path for many tourists but those who go are in for an extraordinary trip back through history. The archaeological treasures here not only show the magnificent palace fortress built by King Herod over two thousand years ago, they also reveal the tunnels and other buildings from the Bar Kochba revolt (c.132 CE) against Rome. It is simply spectacular!

Palace of King Herod built on an artificial hill and also the place where Herod was buried. The tour also includes corridors inside the hill built in the time of  Bar Kochba (rebellion against Rome). Beautiful views of the surroundings and the Bethlehem.

No other archeological site has the combination of features here, which offer an insight into Herod himself. Add the secret passageways of the Jewish rebels and the ancient synagogue, and it is unforgettable. New areas are currently being developed for the public which totally change the site from it has been for 30-some years.

Another excellent Israeli national park.  Herod the Great did enjoy his palace fortresses.  He was a prolific builder and engineer.  Instead of Great, he should have been called Herod the Builder.  
There is ample parking and the ascent isn’t too steep.  The view from any direction is amazing on a clear day.
A truly remarkable place. You do not see many artificial mountains. The walk through the tunnels is extraordinary.
Elias Restaurant was fast, plenty of space, food was good.
Most beautiful religious place, I recommend everyone to visit it

Very good selection of food 
Pleasant staff. Excellent coffee.
Awesome food.. Worth the money
Immersive and amazing place in the middle road from Jerusalem to Bethlehem.

St. Theodosius monastery is one of those ancient desert monasteries that were established in early Byzantine era in Judean desert. This is a place that marks the events described in the gospel of Matthew 2:12. Visit the ancient cave where the wise man spent a night and have a quite time in prayer in the richly decorated church.
Ok
super
Până aici se poate ajunge cu autocarul. Ca să mergi mai departe spre Mănăstirea Sfântul Sava trebuie să te urci de aici în microbuz.

Św. Teodozjusz ur. w Kapadocji w 414 r. W 476 r. zakłada on w tym miejscu klasztor, który staje się centrum cenobityzmu jerozolimskiego (400 uczniów). Klasztor zniszczony podczas najazdu perskiego. Częściowo odnowiony przez prawosławnych Greków w 1898 r. Budowa nowej świątyni zakończona w 1952 r. Wewnątrz krypta z grobem Świętego.
Quiet place and delicious coffee
